dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through whose windows the same light lividly illuminates three space-suited and helmeted ASTRONAUTS -- afraid and curiously hesitant at the controls. We establish a Dual Date Meter showing the year in terms both of "EARTH TIME" and "SELF-TIME". Both panels read: 3955.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1, (MALE)
dialogues.text: Were we wise ... ?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2, (MALE)
dialogues.text: We were agreed. Whoever wins the war, there be no place on Earth for us. We've escaped.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1, (MALE)
dialogues.text: And where are we escaping?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3, (FEMALE)
dialogues.text: (briskly) Probably to our death. But just possibly--

dialogues.speaker: EARTH'S RIM WHITENS TO INCANDESCENCE
dialogues.text: and a soundless explosion sends a column of fire and cloud mushrooming up towards us.

dialogues.speaker: SPACESHIP
dialogues.text: Appalled silence. Through the ship's windows the ASTRONAUTS are watching (and we with them) the nuclear ‘disintegration of Earth. In awed voices:

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: The fools have finally destroyed themselves.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: Earth is dead.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3
dialogues.text: And we live. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 3- Cont. 4

dialogues.speaker: A-4
dialogues.text: The spaceship begins to shudder.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: But for how long? Here comes the shock wave. The shock wave of the huge, megatonic explosion hits the spaceship from below. Chaos and pandemonium inside. We multiply normal air turbulence a thousandfold and are bashed, buffeted, whirled, twirled, lifted a hundred miles and dropped fifty, before slowly flattening out to some semblance of equilibrium on (presumably) anew orbit. The Date Meter digits under "EARTH TIME" have begun to click and race erratically. Meanwhile, the bright, white light of Earth’s final holocaust has slowly faded, as the spaceship's windows fog and blacken. All that can now be heard is frenzied static on the ship's radio. The static begins to cross-fade into (unbelievably yet unmistakably!) a single human voice.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: ..-further student rioting on the campus today at Berkeley Univ... (static) «»-police are standing by to... More static, then the radio goes dead.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: He's speaking our language! I don't understand ... But we, perhaps, begin to. For we notice that the "EARTH TIME" year-digits on the spaceship's Date Meter have been simultaneously clicking back from 3955 to 1973.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: The shock must have ... unbalanced the mechanism. I still don't understand. He is looking at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across it curves the descending graphline which traces optimum re-entry path. Beneath it are three dials. Now (to the roar of released rocket propellant and the wavering of dial-pointers) computer-controlled light- dots begin to trace the spacecraft's actual re-entry Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: A-4 Cont. path, which sometimes slightly deviates to left or right of the graphline but always approximately follows its course.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: We've been forced out of orbit.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: (looking at panel) We're descending.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3
dialogues.text: But where? And indeed the spaceship is being pulled gravitationally back into the atmosphere of:

dialogues.speaker: EARTH
dialogues.text: We are watching it from the P.0.V. of a U.S. Marine Helicopter PILOT flying on normal coastal reconnaissance duty; and the coast itself (as plane banks to include it) is California. All is peaceful, empty and deserted. Until ... PILOT mildly reacts to an object beached on the tideline far below. His prop-blades louden as he goes into a steep investigatory dive. FROM PILOT'S P.0.V. We ZOOM towards the floating and still-unopened spaceship

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he flattens off and reascends:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: (radio-reporting) Tower, this is Red Baron Five. I have an object beached on the tideline -- uh -- seemingly one of our spacecraft. Coordinates are southeast corner of sector Alpha Charlie. Relay this to appropriate recovery forces. Please alert Red Baron Ops and I'll squawk Channel Two for radar fix. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: (on phone) Rescue, we have Red Baron Five report of possible spacecraft washed ashore in southeast sector Alpha Charlie. Immediately launch two copters to effect pickup and recovery. Base Radar will vector your choppers to the location. He picks up second phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER
dialogues.text: The Colonel, please. 10- out 12

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (into phone) I didn't even know we had anything up. ... Okay, I'1]1 call Washington.

dialogues.text: 3-star GENERAL BRODY stands against wall map of splashdow area and barks into phone.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: No serial number? ... Well, it may have been burnt out on re-entry. .. No, neither did I. I'l] check with Deputy Director, NASA, and call you back. He cuts the call to initiate a new one. 14 ouT

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE AT CAPE KENNEDY
dialogues.text: INTERCUTTING DEPUTY DIRECTOR with BRODY in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY DIRECTOR, (CIVILIAN)
dialogues.text: (patiently) General Brody, I'm telling you ... We have no spacecraft up. Cont. 234  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 15 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (irritably) You're telling me that what never went up can't come down. And I'm telling you it just has. And now I'm going to tell the President. 16- our CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BB-18
dialogues.text: The PRESIDENT is an articulate, unruffled professional politician with a flair for irony. Into phone:

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Let us hope and pray that you are right, General. But I think we should be alert to a remoter possibility: that the Russians retrieved one of our missing space- ships and remanned it with astronauts who have now accidentally splashed down in our own territorial waters. In the event they're still alive, I suggest you order the helicopter to lift the spaceship out of the ocean unopened ... You have? Good. Then should not be opened until landed at air base under armed military surveillance. (drily) And General. This is not for the networks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO

dialogues.text: From squawk box we hear:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) Rescue squadron approaching base one seven five point three. Spaceship secured and in tow. Request landing procedure. We hear the hum of 0.8. helicopter(s) approaching. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: BB-18 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: DUTY OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: c-18 INSIDE SPACESHIP Its windows still fogged and blackened; its OCCUPANTS still helmeted. Muffled helicopter hum behind:

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: We're prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 3
dialogues.text: Yes -- but whose?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 1
dialogues.text: The voice spoke our language. At least they have Intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRONAUT 2
dialogues.text: (urgently) Then at least let us conceal our own intelligence from our captors. Until we have their measure, our safety lies in silence.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: p-18 out

dialogues.speaker: EXT, AIRFIELD
dialogues.text: Helicopter hum loudens. From a large open truck in f.g. (flanked by MARINES with rifles at the ready) we hear and then see the copters approaching. Copter 2 lands. Copter 1 deposits spaceship in rear of truck and flies out of shot. Truck moves off and we FOLLOW it through a "corridor" of armed MARINES into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where the COLONEL, a CAPTAIN (Officer of the Day) and armed ESCORT are waiting. The hangar doors clang shut. We STAY on COLONEL and CAPTAIN, still tensely waiting, as appropriate SOUND EFFECTS herald:

dialogues.speaker: A-20 THE OPENING OF THE SPACESHIP'S HATCH
dialogues.text: Our helmeted ASTRONAUTS emerge; descend; and draw them- selves up, line abreast, facing: 234

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Welcome, gentlemen. Then both their faces stiffen in aghast astonishment, as we: CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FROM THEIR P.O.V,.
dialogues.text: They are all chimpanzees. One of them (MILO) is a character new to our series. The other two are CORNELIUS and his wife ZIRA.

dialogues.speaker: A RED TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: Silent for a beat. Then its ring stabs the silence. It continues ringing until a Presidential HAND picks it up, when MUSIC (urgently suggestive of Morse Code) hits:

dialogues.speaker: TITLE AND CREDITS
dialogues.text: Over this we see a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A. Secret Communications: green phones, purple phones, scramblers, hectic switchboards, yards of telex in cipher, sheaves of memos en clair - the lot! B. At Air Base: gates locked, furloughs cancelled, perimeter guard doubled, as also "KEEP OUT" security signs. MONTAGE ENDS, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: who is carrying a large paper bag, as they walk past HQ buildings.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Did you call the Zoo? Cont. 234  234

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. We're in luck. The sick bay's almost empty except for a mauled fox cub, a deer with pneumonia, ea depressed gorilla and a camel. The Apes will be hidden from the public. They'll be quarantined. If they want medical attention, it's available on the spot. And the experts can start giving them the once-over first thing in the morning. General Brody's very pleased.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Me, too. Can't have a lot of monkeys making messes in the Guard House. Have we fed them? Like raw steak or something.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The Zoo tells me that chimpanzees, like all apes, are vegetarian, sir.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (indicating paper bag) They suggested oranges. They have reached:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: whose door is unlocked by an obviously shaken Guard Commander (SERGEANT).

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Sergeant? SERGEANT helplessly ushers them into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's rear section (behind bars) is furnished with austere serviceable beds, chairs, tables and a washing sink with plates and cutlery in rack above. On the floor: a capacio rawhide valise, from which ZIRA (gloved and shod) has extracted a robe into which she is changing. Her discarde space suit lies et her feet. MILO and CORNELIUS have alre changed. Their space suit are hanging neatly from wall hooks. At COLONEL'S entry, MILO and CORNELIUS rise courteously to their feet, while ZIRA struggles hastily i her robe. From the threshold: Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 28 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (automatically) Excuse me. I didn't mean to disturb... (aghast to Captain) What am I saying?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: They're ... pretending to dress.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: What d'you mean, pretending? They are dressing. Where'd they get those Clothes?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (indicating valise) They brought them with them, sir. (gulping) In a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Suit...? (with an effort; to Captain) Greg, give them their oranges. CAPTAIN advances cautiously with paper bag. 2g MASTER SHOT We HOLD COLONEL and SERGEANT talking in f.g., while CAPTAIN proffers oranges (which the TRIO gracefully accepts) in b.g. ZIRA, holding her orange, has gone straight to the sink rack, from which she takes three plates, three knives and three forks.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (not noticing; to Sergeant) Arrange prisoner escort for 1630 hours ... ZIRA distributes plates and cutlery to MILO and CORNELIUS To CAPTAIN's astonishment, the APES draw up chairs and si round the table.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (not noticing; to Sergeant) We're sending them to the Zoo Infirmary. -34 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: ey Cont. The APES start meticulously quartering their oranges on their plates with their knives.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (still to Sergeant) They'll have company. There's a gorilla in the next cage. ZIRA, overhearing this, reacts violently; rises, picks up her plate and hurls it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: (looking round at last Now why the hell did it do that? The full implications of the plates and the knives only strike him as we:

dialogues.speaker: A-30
dialogues.text: our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We START on CLOSE SHOT of the deer with pneumonia, cradle under ultraviolet lamps which (as we PULL BACK) prove to the huge, clinically furnished room's only light source - for the sick animals must get their rest. We PAN past a recumbent camel and mauled fox cub, into whose small slee pody the rubber tube of a suspended flask is intravenousl dripping plasma; and END on a white-coated KEEPER (with flashlamp) inspecting our APE TRIO, now installed in one two large, contiguous cages at the dim room's center: str for them to lie on; a bowl of water for drinking; and a generous supply of oranges and bananas, one of which he cautiously proffers to ZIRA through the bars, while playf patting her head. ZIRA rejects the banana and sleps his face. Taken aback but still amicably:

dialogues.speaker: KEEPER
dialogues.text: Have it your own way, mate. Clang! He locks them in and exits. When the light from hi flashlamp has faded to near-darkness, we hear an outer do more distantly locked.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (outraged whisper to Cornelius) I'm not his mate. I'm yours.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, please control yourself. I think they're trying to be kind.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: This cage stinks of gorilla. She sits down disconsolately on the straw. Instantly CORNELIUS sits by her and takes her hand. In undertones:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Cornelius -- where are we? What's happened? CORNELIUS helplessly shrugs. From the shedows, very softl

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: I know where we are. I know what has happened. ZIRA and CORNELIUS stare at him. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: A-30 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: In some fashion -- and I lack the intellect to know precisely how -- we have traveled from Earth's future into Earth's past.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: But we saw Earth destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And Earth will be destroyed -- just as we saw it. Only, since seeing it, we have passed through @ ... backward disturbance in time -- did you notice the Date Meter clicking down after the shock wave hit our ship? -- and we have returned to Earth almost two thousand years before its destruction. (solemnly) That is another reason for keeping silence. Our human captors would not be edified to know that, one day, their world will crack like an egg and fry to a cinder, because of an Ape war of aggression. His low tones have become just emphatic enough to disturb

dialogues.speaker: GORILLA IN NEXT CAGE
dialogues.text: It shifts, grunts and whimpers uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The TRIO reacts. We CLOSE to:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Apes, at this instant in time, cannot yet talk. For the moment, we should follow their example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear occasional call of a tropical early bird, and CLOSE to two human early birds: LEWIS DIXON, a young animal psychiatrist, and his pretty (female) research assistant, STEVIE. As they walk:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (feeling in pocket) The driver brought a report from the Air Base. (scanning it) The usual imitatory behavior.... mimicking salutes...hand-shaking ..-Bitting on chairs...eating off plates with knives...but -- He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What, Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: There was a sort of rawhide valise in the ship.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: With food?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: No -- clothes. Stevie, they changed into them. We have reached the Infirmary's main (open) door which th enter after showing passes to 2 SOLDIERS on guard outside

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (undertone) Join the Army and see the Zoo...

dialogues.speaker: APES' CAGE
dialogues.text: where KEEPER is already on duty, sweeping debris clear of intelligence test apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Hi, Arthur. Cont. 234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 32 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Hi, Dr. Dixon....Miss Stevie. Our APES survey them stonily.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (fingering bruise on cheek) The female's a bit uppity, sir. Cont. 234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 32 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll be careful. Set up the Wisconsin Multiphasic. This is a screen which can be lowered and raised (like @ window shade) between the Investigator on one side and the Subject on the other. ZIRA winks knowledgeably at CORNELIUS, who winks back. MILO gestures them into more discreet behavior. KEEPER sets up apparatus during:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (to Stevie) Unless the spacecraft was remotely controlled, they must have been conditioned to press at least some of the right buttons. They can't be morons. (to Keeper) The female first, Arthur. And set up Tic-Tac-Toe. To everyone's surprise and KEEPER's reliet, ZIRA promptly squats down on her side of the raised screen. The hyper- cautious MILO disapprovingly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: She knows this one. All right -- let's make it difficult. He lowers screen and displays a single red cube for three seconds before reraising screen to mask ZIRA's view. When he lowers it again, he is simultaneously displaying a blue pyramid, a green cone, a yellow sphere, @ blue cube, a red octohedron and the red cube. ZIRA instantly selects the red cube, which she offers courteously back to LEWIS. LEWIS gives an astonished whistle; rewards ZIRA with a handful of raisins, which she promptly eats; and STEVIE retrieves her notepad which has fallen from her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (indicating screen to Stevie) You can take that away.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Tic-Tac-Toe, Arthur. (indicating Cornelius) With that male. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 32 Cont.1 CORNELIUS, in obedience to a warning glance from MILO, permits himself to be led by the KEEPER's hand to one side of the Tic-Tac-Toe screen. ZIRA is already seated enthusiastically at the other, ready to press panel- button combinations which will dictate the positioning of the noughts and crosses; and after a brief skirmish with CORNELIUS, ZIRA achieves a row of noughts. Whereat she rises to her feet, clasps her hands above her head like a boxer acknowledging victory and retires to a corner, where she sits in triumph on one of a half-a- dozen oddly constructed wooden boxes.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (rewarding Zira with raisins) Get her off that box, Arthur. (determined to win) We're going to need it. KEEPER cautiously approaches ZIRA, who puts a hand on his proffered arm and graciously rises -- while STEVIE scatters the boxes about the cage and puts a banana well out of ZIRA's reach between the upper bars. This is a test unfamiliar to ZIRA, who responds to its challenge. She speculatively eyes the banana; then stoops to prowl among the boxes, which she carefully examines without touching them. Then she straightens +. and thinks. The tension is insupportable. Suddenly ZIRA, moving into action, interlocks all the boxes so that they form a somewhat eccentric staircase leading to the banana. Having done so, she folds her arms and smugly stands at the "staircase's" foot. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 32 Cont.2

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Why doesn't she climb?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Because I loathe and detest bananas.

dialogues.speaker: ' CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira! As though in a slow nightmare, STEVIE sags and faints. Somehow, LEWIS catches her and lowers her to the cage floor. Somehow, KEEPER sluices water from the (refilled) drinking bowl over her upturned face. As she recovers:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (sweating) Help me get her away. I'l] come back. Jointly supporting STEVIE, they leave the cage, which KEEPER locks. We STAY with:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Zira, are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Dr. Milo, please don't call my wife mad.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: (evenly) I did not call her mad. I merely asked her if she was. And I repeat the question. (to Zira) Are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I hate deceit.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: There is a time for truth and a time, not for lies, but for silence. Until we know who is our friend and who our enemy--

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: And how in the name of God are we to know that, unless we communicate? We can speak. So I spoke.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: We can also listen ... Cont. 234  234 REVISED - “THE SECRET OF THE PLANET OF THE APES" - 10/2/7 33 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: To a lot of psychiatric small talk --

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: And we can watch ...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: A display of primitive apparatus --

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (kicking the apparatus) Primitive? It's prehistoric. It couldn't test the intelligence of a newt. She kicks the apparatus again, and it collapses. The GORILLA in the next cage gives a disturbed grunt.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, calm yourself --

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I am caln. She knocks another piece of apparatus endways. Now even MILO's self-control snaps. He stalks to the side bars and (with eyes screwed shut in frustration) briefly but fiercely shakes them before spinning round, with back pressed against the bars, to glare at his two tormentors. We SHOOT AT AND PAST HIM into the next cage where the GORILLA now shambles to its feet and slowly advances from b.g., during:

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Stop arguing. It's too late for that. His body masks the GORILLA's crouched and stealthy approach from them -- but not from us.

dialogues.speaker: MILO
dialogues.text: Stop arguing and start thinking. Now that they know we can speak, how much shall we tell them? How--

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (screaming) Milo-o-o! Through the bars, two hairy hands converge on MILO's throat and strangle him to death. The roaring of the GORILLA, the throttled cries of MILO and ZIRA's screams combine to launch:  234

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of alarmed birds and beasts as panic briefly infects the Zoo. E.g., a sleeping owl. opens huge eyes; cranes cry; mallards take off from pool; seals cough; apes gibber; tigers snarl; lions roar, and elephants trumpet. We might (instead of separating each cry) overlay sound cumulatively so that each new noise is added to its predecessors, as we build visually and aurally toa massive and bestial crescendo before TIME DISSOLVING ack tos

dialogues.speaker: THE CAGE
dialogues.text: The "panic™ is over. Outside, two OFFICIALS confer in murmurs with LEWIS. As KEEPERS 1 and 2 lift a blanketed stretcher and carry MILO's body out of shot:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 1
dialogues.text: We shall want a full autopsy...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 2
dialogues.text: With particular emphasis on the cranial and oral areas.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL 1
dialogues.text: Keep him in cold storage till the report's in. Then send him to Taxidermy. (wryly) He's a museum piece. A low moan turns everyone's head towards the cage's interior. ZIRA sits crouched in a corner, her head in her hands and rocking from side to side. CORNELIUS is comforting her. LEwIS (to Officials) I'd better do this alone. They nod and leave. LEWIS enters the cage; looks compassionately at the two huddled APES, the straw, the orange peels, the bananas, the abandoned intelligence test apparatus.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (gently) We mean you no harm, Silence and stillness. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 35- Cont. 6 3

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Do you understand? We mean you no harm. Slowly and bitterly, ZIRA points an ironic and accusing finger at the next cage, where an anesthetized and chaine GORILLA slumps in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: But he isn't us. He's your own kind.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (angrily on her feet in a flash) He's a gorilla. As CORNELIUS soothes her:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I mean he's of your own genus. He's an Ape. Look. You don't have to be afraid. We've put him in chains and under sedation. Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I should. I've been doing it half my life to Humans.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) Humans?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (as though this explained everything) I'm a psychiatrist. A second shock. LEWIS covers dazed eyes with his hand and after a struggle, regains his self-control.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: So am I. And I mean you no harn.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (at last) We know that. LEWIS, over one hurdle, exhales. Cont. 234

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: My name is Cornelius. And this is Zira -- my wife.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Mine is Lewis -- Lewis Dixon. He diffidently extends a hand. CORNELIUS takes it. ZIRA doesn't.

Cc. Inside hotel, at Reception, CLERK proffers Visitors! Book. ZIRA hesitates over "ADDRESS"; then writes "The Zoo". PAGE takes the rawhide valise. They ascend (sensation!) by elevator to: Cont. 234  234 REVISED - “THE SECRET OF THE PLANET OF THE APES" - 9/30/7 51 Cont.1 D. Their flower-filled suite, which contains endless gift baskets (from members of the public) piled high with bananas. Two further gifts (with cards attached) are a small seesaw and a stationary bicycle. STEVIE is on her knees unwrapping ... a child's multicolored rubber ball. We move from sitting room through bedroom to bathroom, where ZIRA discovers two hygienically wrapped toothbrushes; unwraps one and begins to brush her hair with it. CORNELIUS sniffs at and cautiously nibbles (ugh!) a cake of soap. LEWIS indicates how to turn on bath taps. CORNELIUS bends over bath to turn on tap. The pointer points to SHOWER and he is drenched. Back in Mercedes passing the Beverly Theater, which is unfortunately reviving "King Kong". CORNELIUS with LEWIS at Carroll & Company. A TAILOR removes his tape from around CORNELIUS's chest.

dialogues.speaker: TAILOR
dialogues.text: May I measure your inside leg, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (coldly) No. A fashion show at Elizabeth the First for ZIRA and STEVIE only. The dazzled ZIRA chooses a high-necked, long-sleeved maxi-skirted evening gown which is very diamante’. Rancho Golf Course. Coached by LEWIS, CORNELIUS in outrageous golf clothes flukily drives 300 yards off the tee. We FOLLOW ball to lip of hole on green and PAN BACK to golf cart approaching. LEWIS hands putter to CORNELIUS, who drives ball another 300 yards, slicing a large divot from the hole's lip. Cocktail party to Press on Beverly Hilton roof. Over sound of chatter and clinking glasses, we START on TIGHT CLOSEUP of ZIRA (in her diamante’ gown) being interviewed by:

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: (notebook poised) What is your favorite fruit? PAN to CORNELIUS being interviewed by:

dialogues.speaker: MALE REPORTER
dialogues.text: And how do you find our women, Mr. Cornelius? Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 51 Cont.2 52 53 55 After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (diplomatically) Very human. MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: LEWIS is maneuvering cork from a half bottle of champagne

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: It's really only grape juice plus. You could each have a sip. As cork pops we ANGLE DOWN on CLOSEUP of glass held by ZIRA, and TIME DISSOLVE from its bubbles to:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: lying in bubble bath. PULL BACK to include CORNELIUS in fancy pajamas, peering down at her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (wrinkling nose) How's it feel?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Wet -- but very soothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE and LEWIS exhaustedly leaving lobby.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: What's for tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: NBC have asked Hasslein to take Zira round the Museum of Science and Industry, and CBS want Cornelius to see a prizefight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over MUSIC, we start on rose garden in front of which ZIRA and HASSLEIN alight from arriving Mercedes. A TV CAMERA, DIRECTOR and CREW follow them up steps into: Cont.

dialogues.speaker: A-55 INT, MUSEUM
dialogues.text: With MUSIC CONTINUING, they are met by CURATOR, who (miming "spiel") conducts them past skeleton of duck-bill dinosaur in Main Hall to darkened Animal Room with (at th far end) its vividly lit, tropically realistic bush table of African elephants, whose trumpeting the MUSIC mimics. Then RIGHT into connecting passage where ZIRA confronts (our own model of) a majestic gorilla with dead, glass ey We TILT DOWN all feet of the gorilla to include ZIRA looking up at it ... and HASSLEIN looking intently at ZIR She staggers slightly, as though giddy.

dialogues.speaker: MUSEUM'S APE SECTION
dialogues.text: ZIRA faints into HASSLEIN's arms. MUSIC OUT.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (to o.s. Curator) It must have been the shock...

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (opening eyes; straight into camera Shock, my foot. I'm pregnant. NOTE: From here on, ZIRA's clothes will need increasing padding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZIRA resting on sofa, with HASSLEIN hovering in oddly oversolicitous attendance.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: I shan't leave you till Cornelius comes back...No, no, I insist. Is there anything I can get you?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I have a strange craving --

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: That is only natural --

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: -- for Grape Juice Plus. As Hasslein reacts, mystified: Cont. 234  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 58 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: It's in the... (new word) .--re-frig-er-ator. With a secret look of curious satisfaction, HASSLEIN extracts and unstoppers the complimentary bottle of champagne and pours it generously into a sizeable wine goblet, which he places on a low table beside her.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Lewis said only a sip.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (eagerly) I assure you it's an excellent restorative -- especially in cases of pregnancy. How long have you known?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (sipping) Since well before the war. It was another reason for escaping. HASSLEIN draws up a chair, takes a lighter and cigarette case from his pocket, then "checks" himself. ZIRA drinks, during:

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Forgive me. In view of your condition, I shouldn't smoke. He repockets lighter but does something with his thumb to the "cigarette case" which he leaves on the low table. We CLOSE to it, during:

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Who won your war? Back to:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (drinking) It wasn't our war. It was the gorilla's war. Chimpanzees are pashy... (the champagne is working) ...-pacifists. We stayed behind. We never saw the enemy. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 58 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: But which side won?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (drinking) Neither.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (refreshing her glass) How do you know that if you weren't there? We can continue to INTERCUT the "cigarette case", during:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (slurred) When we were in space...we saw @ bright, white, blinding light. We saw the rim of Earth melt. Then there was...a tornado in the sky. She hiccups and slops a little champagne on the table top HASSLEIN instantly lifts the "cigarette case" and (after mopping the wet patch dry) carefully replaces it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I feel magnificently sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (earnestiy) Zira, was there a Date Meter in the spaceship?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Mn.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: What did it register after Earth's destruction?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Nineteen...seventy...three. We CLOSE to CLOSEUP of "CIGARETTE CASE".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And before? Before the white light and the tornado?

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: "CIGARETTE CASE" on DIFFERENT TABLE TOP

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (0.8.3 filtered) Thirty-nine...fifty...something. As HASSLEIN clicks off and opens up the bugging device, w PULL BACK to reveal HASSLEIN and the PRESIDENT in:

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: (coolly) So?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (hotly) So you have evidence, Mr. President, that one day talking Apes will dominate the Earth and finally destroy it in thirty-nine fifty-something.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: (massive calm) I doubt if we shall still be in office by then. (opening a file) And according to the NASA experts, who are still subjecting the spaceship to microscopic scrutiny, the precise year of what you merely infer to be Earth's destruction is recorded on the flight synthesizer as thirty-nine fifty-five. (a beat.) A.D., presumably. HASSLEIN discomfited.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Now what do you expect me and the United Nations -- though not necessarily in that order -- to do about it? Alter what zou believe to be the course of the future by Slaughtering two Innocents -- or rather three, now that one of them's pregnant? Herod tried that, and Christ survived.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Herod lacked our facilities. Cont.  234 60 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: He also became unpopular. Historically unpopular. And we don't want that, do we?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (aghast) Are you actually saying--

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: I'm saying that our two visitors seem really very charming and peaceable people -- or rather creatures -- and that the voters love them.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Do you want them and their progeny to dominate the world?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Well, not at the next election. But one day, if the progeny turn out to be as nice as the parents -- who knows? They might make a better job of it than we did.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: By destroying the world?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Are you sure that what they saw destroyed was the world?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: I consider it dispassionately as a possibility -- not hysterically as a fact. winces.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: This isn't the Bay of Pigs. It's the Bay of Apes. We don't have a mere twenty-four hours to make up our minds. We have... (calculating on pad) +..one thousand nine hundred and eighty-two years. Let us not, in the vernacular of my day, ‘blow our cool’, Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I cannot feel ‘cool' about even the possibility of Earth's destruction -- however far distant.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Neither can I, Hasslein, neither can I. But are we sure it was -- or will be -- the Apes who destroyed it? (flipping through tile) In the afternoon session they admitted to rifles...machine guns...canon...I find no evidence of a nuclear weapon in their armory. (significantly) I can in ours.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: We have their own testimony that they provoked the war.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: And they seem to have provoked a pretty thoroughly into the argain. I'm not saying you're wrong, Hasslein. I'm saying that before I have them shot against a wall, I want convincing that the writing on the wall is calculably true. ‘ow. Convince me.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (rising and pacing) By their testimony, we know that Apes will acquire the power of intelligent speech and become the master race on Earth. By Zira's testimony, we know that she is pregnant with child. By my own testimony, it would be genetically possible for this child -- provided always that we permit its birth -- (a sharp glance from the President) -- to bear or to beget a talking Ape by or from a dumb one in a present-day jungle or a present-day ZOO. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: And do you truly believe that by deliberate, present-day action we can neutralize that possibility? That we can alter the future?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: But do you believe that we should? Given the ability to alter the future, have we the right to do so? HASSLEIN buries his head in his hands; then looks up at the PRESIDENT with genuine unhappiness.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mr. President. I've wrestled with this, and I don't know. How many futures are there? And which future has God, if there is a God, chosen for Man's final destiny? If I urge the destruction of these Apes, am I defying God's will or obeying it? Am I God's enemy or His instrument?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: An assassin would say the latter. Do you approve of assassination?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: We condoned the attempted assassination of Hitler because he was evil.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: But would we have approved killing him in babyhood when he was still innocent? Or killing his mother when he was still in her womb? Or slaughtering his remote ancestors? We have no evidence, Hasslein, that these Apes are evil.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: There are indications.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: (sharply) Such as? Cont. REVISED - “ESCAPE FROM THE PLANET OF THE APES" - 10/23/7 60 Cont.3 61 out A-61 INT. 234

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: There were hesitancies and small discrepancies in their answers to the Commission which suggest that, if properly interrogated --

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting they were improperly interrogated?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Shall I say ‘unprofessionally'?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: You want them given the works by the C.I.A. or something?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: The full works, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: Then tell that to the Commission. I will abide by their findings.

dialogues.speaker: FEDERAL BUILDING
dialogues.text: COMMISSION sitting. On the dais, the CHAIRMAN reads. HASSLEIN, smiling, sits beside him. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: A-61 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN
dialogues.text: Therefore, having convened in secret session, the Commission makes the following interim recommendations: One: The Public should be Informed that the Ape-onauts,, after their arduous space voyage and the fatigue arising from its attendant publicity, are to be afforded rest and privacy in a location whose identity will not be divulged. They will then be found research employment suited to their high intellectual capacities. Two: Since, however, there is Justifiable cause for suspecting that they have withheld vital information from the Commission, the Ape-onauts will in fact be secretly conducted by their 'keeper', Dr. Lewis Dixon... (we pick him out, deadpan) +..to the location known as Camp Eleven and held there, in his care, for interrogation by officers of the C.I.A. under the guidance and supervision of Dr. Otto Hasslein. HASSLEIN'S smile is like a skull's.

dialogues.speaker: B-61 WHITE HOUSE OFFICE
dialogues.text: PRESIDENT reading the speech's continuation to HASSLEIN.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT
dialogues.text: 'Three: On the interrogation's completion, the Commission will reconvene to discuss its findings and make such further recommendations as may be deemed just and/or expedient.' (to Hasslein) I find that ‘and/or' somewhat sinister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: winding through bare, hilly country at DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS speaks to rearview mirror which reflects CORNELIUS ZIRA in backseat.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (troubled) I wish I knew how to advise you. They may try to make you angry -- put don't be, or you'll be trapped into wrong answers. Try to keep polite.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: You hear that, Zira. ZIRA stares grimly ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: For the baby's sake. She nods. Through the windshield, the Camp gate distantly looms, during:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: And above all, don't tell them what you told me. He halts at the security-signed gate; shows his pass and/ or badge to GUARD, who breaks the electric circuit by ins key in lock of metal wall box just inside his window. To CORNELIUS'S fascination, the gate latch clicks and GUARD opens gates manually -- saluting as they pass through.

dialogues.speaker: DEEPENING DUSK
dialogues.text: The GUARD clangs the iron grille of the gate shut in our faces. We Z00M to its security sign: It says: "DANGER". We FADE TO a:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered and tipsy) When we were in space...we saw a bright, white, blinding light... The tape stops with a click. We hear a switch being depressed, and. CUT IN:  234

dialogues.speaker: A LIGHT
dialogues.text: of almost solar intensity, swiveling into CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Brighter than this? The light is shining on:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: 43 She screws her dazzled eyes shut, then slowly opens them reconfront:

dialogues.speaker: HER THREE EXAMINERS
dialogues.text: HASSLEIN seated between E.1 (amiable) and E.2 (icy) at a table on which stands the lamp that dazzled ZIRA. HASSLEI presses a button.

dialogues.speaker: PULLING BACK FROM ZIRA
dialogues.text: to include CORNELIUS listening nervously by her side. a wall speaker:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered and tipsy) We saw the rim of Earth melt. Then there was...a tornado in the sky.

dialogues.speaker: E.1
dialogues.text: (amiably to Zira) It's your voice, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: E.2
dialogues.text: (icily) He does say 80.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: How can I tell? I don't even remember.

dialogues.speaker: E.1
dialogues.text: What don't you remember, Zira?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I don't remember what I said to Dr. Hass-- Cont. From  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 69 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: E.2
dialogues.text: (triumphant) So you did say something.

dialogues.speaker: E.1
dialogues.text: Why don't you remember?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Because Dr. Hasslein made me drunk.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (suave) Deliberately. In vino veritas.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: E.2
dialogues.text: He means you always tell the truth if you're stoned.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (rising in distress) Who is going to stone my wife?

dialogues.speaker: E.2
dialogues.text: (seizing on the misunderstanding) I'll tell you who'll stone her. The People will stone her when they nd out that, one day, talking monkeys.... (Cornelius reacts) «.-are going to bust the whole world wide open and bring it blazing about our goddamned ears.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (polite but firmly) Please do not use the word monkey. We find it offensive.

dialogues.speaker: E.1
dialogues.text: (quietly to Zira) Why did you tell something to Dr. Hasslein when drunk, which you never told to the Commission when sober? Because you and your husband were afraid for the safety of yourselves...and your unborn child? Cont. 4h

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 69 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (perturbed) I withheld nothing. Nobody asked me. E.1. And if somebody had? After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I should have said that Chimpanzees had no part in it. Only the Gorillas and the Orang-utans. E.2. You all look alike to me.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (stung) And I should have said that we possessed no weapon capable of causing such destruction. E.2. Then who did?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: God, if there is a God? Man, if he'd survived somewhere in more sophisticated form? He glares at E.2., who stares coldly back. E.2. Are you trying to make a monkey out of me?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (pounding desk) Please do not use that word! As an archeologist I had access to history scrolls kept secret from the masses, and I know that one reason for Man's original downfall was your peculiar habit of murdering one another. Man destroys Man. Apes do not destroy Apes. Cont. 234  234

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (cooling the heat) Cornelius, this is not an inter- racial hassle but a search for facts. We admit the possibility of Man's de@line and fall. But what all of us here would like to know is how Apes rose. The emotional temperature drops.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (unexpectedly ) It began, in our prehistory, with the plague that fell upon dogs.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: And cats.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Hundreds and thousands of them died. And hundreds and thousands had to be destroyed to prevent the spread of the infection.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: There were dog bonfires... For the first time we see a tape recorder (concealed from the APES) slowly revolving.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: By the time the plague was contained, Man was without pets; and for Man, this was intolerable. He might kill his brother, but he could not kill his dog. So Humans took primitive Apes as pets.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Primitive and dumb, but still twenty times more intelligent than dogs or cats.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: They were quartered in cages, but they lived and moved freely in human houses. They became responsive to human speech. And in the course of only two centuries progressed from performing mere tricks to performing services. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 69 Cont.3 E.1. Like sheep dogs...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Could a sheep dog cook? Could a sheep dog clean the house? Or go marketing for groceries with a list from its mistress? Or wait on tables?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (with dangerous pride) Or, after three more centuries, turn the tables on their owners?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: H (instantly) low? CORNELIUS laye a restraining hand on. ZIRA's.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: They became alert to the concept of Slavery and (as their numbers grew) to slavery's antidote, which is unity. They began to assemble in Bmall bands. They learned the art of corporate and militant action. They learned to refuse. We INTERCUT concealed tape recorder, inexorably revolving Then back to: The tape ZIRA and

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: At first they barked their refusal. And then, on a historic day commemorated by my species and fully documented in the secret scrolls, there came an Ape called Aldo, who didn't bark. He articulated. He spoke a word which had been spoken to him, time without number, by Humans. He said 'No'. recorder revolves. E.1. So that's how it 411 started. CORNELIUS exchange troubled glances.

dialogues.speaker: BASSLEIN
dialogues.text: How did it end? Cont.  49 69 Cont.5

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (stalling) End? E.2. E-N-D -- end. How were the Humans when you left? A silence. E.2. Were they happy?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (stalling) You could say so. E.2. I'm asking you to say so. He pulls the intercom on the table a shade nearer.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Then I'll say so. They were happy. E.2. (buzzing intercom) Clip One, please. From a wall speaker:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) Wnere we come from, Apes talk and Humans are dumb. E.2. You recognize your husband's words to the Commission?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Yes. E.2. So they were happy -- and dumb.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (seeing where this will lead) I - I think he must have meant dumb-stupid -- not dumb-mute. Cont. 234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 69 Cont.6 E.2. (to Cornelius) Is that what you meant? CORNELIUS cannot meet his cold stare. E.2. (to intercom) Clip Two. From the wall speaker:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) As to Humans, I've dissec--examined thousands of them and, until now, I've only discovered two who could talk in my life. E.2. What did the others do? Sing? ZIRA shakes her head. E.2. Was one of the two who talked Colonel Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I never met Colonel Taylor. E.2. (to intercom) Repeat first three seconds of Clip Two. From the wall speaker:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) As to Humans, I've dissec-- examined thousands of them --~- The sound cuts out. E.2. What was the word you didn't finish?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (frightened) I can't remember. Cont. 234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 69 Cont.7 E.2. (to intercom) Play the loop. From the wall speaker:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) Dissec ... Dissec ... Dissec ... The loop continues playing, intolerably, during: E.2. Complete the word, monkey. Complete the word.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (filtered) Dissec ... Dissec ... Dissec ...

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (with a touch of her old spirit) It sounds as if I had hiccups. With a snort of contempt, E.2. flicks off intercom and wall speaker to look inquiringly at E.1., who in his turn looks inquiringly at HASSLEIN.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (nods ) Send for Dr. Dixon. E.2. (to intercom) Send Dr. Dixon in, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Striding anxiously towards a door, whose GUARD admits him. We FOLLOW LEWIS through:

dialogues.speaker: CLINICAL OUTER ROOM
dialogues.text: Predominantly white. A wheeled couch, a stretcher with medical apparatus, chairs and a desk with tne inevitable tape recorder. From here LEWIS enters:

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Ah. Dr. Dixon. He is holding something wrapped in cotton, which he hands to LEWIS.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Please take the female into the next room and administer this. LEWIS raises hostile, inquiring eyebrows as he unwraps the cotton.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Sodium Pentothal. Seven and a half grains. The cotton contains e& charged hypodermic.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
