dialogues.text: Look, I only lost my temper and hurt him. It isn't as though I'd killed him. But if we go on like this, it may kill you.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (struggling to rise) It's better now. I can walk.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (holding her down) They may punish us. But at least the baby will be born. (settling her in the dip) You'll be safe here. I'11l come back with help. off into the darkness. cuT TO:  234 101 102 103 73

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS'S CAR DRIVING SLOWLY RIGHT
dialogues.text: He peers from side to side; approaches freeway on-ramp; hesitates; then frustratedly shakes his head, accelerates and enters freeway.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE'S STATION WAGON DRIVING SLOWLY LEFT
dialogues.text: She peers at the bushes out of which CORNELIUS peered in Scene 89; drives on end recedes.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS APPROACHING LIGHTS
dialogues.text: They turn out to belong to an isolated gas station. CORNELIUS walks nervously towards a lighted window in its rear. Inside, the radio is broadcasting a variety program, whose (filtered) voices louden as CORNELIUS draws near: “WIFE" Honey, our doctor says I need making love to at least five times a week.

dialogues.speaker: "HUSBAND"
dialogues.text: Put me down for twice. A roar of studio laughter, suddenly faded out. CORNELIUS is about to tap on window (where a fat ATTENDANT sits listening) when he hears:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: We interrupt) this program for an urgent news flash. The Ape-onauts are wanted for murder. The body of twenty-two-year-old Hank Svenson, a medical orderly presently attached to... CRESCENDO MUSIC (drowning announcement) mimics the high- string scream in CORNELIUS's head. He blocks both ears with his hands. Then, as his guts tighten and twist, he clutches his belly and runs from gas station. The "scream thins and fades behind:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (receding) ...cannot have gone far. Any person sighting the killers should not repeat not try to apprehend them but immediately contact... CORNELIUS is out of earshot, breathing hard. He recovers; takes his bearings, and shambles off in Zira's direction.

dialogues.speaker: APPROACHES...
dialogues.text: «..passes and recedes.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS REJOINING ZIRA
dialogues.text: She is ... sleeping? He touches her. She doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Zira! Still no movement. He shakes her -- almost roughly.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (louder) Zira! She stirs and opens dog-tired eyes. He sighs with momentary relief. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, I killed him.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (struggling up, alarmed) who?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: The Orderly at the Camp. He's dead. I hetrd it spoken over the air. She sits up, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Everybody's hunting for us, Zira. She begins piteously to moan and whimper. He holds her head against his chest, but the whimpering continues. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Hush. Still, the whimpering.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Hush, Zira! He puts a hand over her muzzle; and in the silence we, too, hear ... a car slowly approaching. Both APES freeze. CORNELIUS peers through a gap in the bushes at:  234 106 107 108 109 75

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTENING...
dialogues.text: ..-in the glow of approaching o.s. headlights. Then the headlights enter shot.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS WITH ZIRA
dialogues.text: His eyes straining. At length:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: It's Stevie's car. He half-rises, cups a hand to his mouth, as though about to shout; sensibly desists; and, instead, picks up a small rock which he throws at station wagon as it passes. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which (mildly) cracks without splintering. STEVIE peers out at:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS CARRYING ZIRA
dialogues.text: Station wagon draws up quietly by roadside.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: She's in labor. He helps ZIRA into rear section, where there are blankets and pulls the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (softly) Poor darling ... (starting a U-turn) Hide under the blankets. The news is bad.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: I know. I heard it ... announced. Stevie, I didn't mean to kill him. He was teasing Zira and I hit him with a tray. He tripped and cracked his head on the table. Please believe-- Cont.  76 109 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I do, Cornelius, I do. But they won't. U-turn completed, she is driving quietly back along highway.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Stevie, you won't take us back to the Camp ...?

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (ghost of a smile) No. Lewis and I have a better idea.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 110 wea Tet CLOSE SHOT - A DARK, DAPPER, HANDSOME MAN - GH’ In his 40's and, seemingly, of Latin extraction.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (deadpan) You are asking the impossible! But... (dazzling smile) ...for you, I have done it. We PULL BACK to include LEWIS peeling off his leather Jjerkin in an elegant caravan whose walls are plastered with handbills for "/.RMANDO'S CIRCUS". As LEWIS hangs his jerkin on a hook:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: And for your two distinguished friends.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (ruefully) Notorious, now.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: To hell with notoriety! What is a husband expected to do? Stand by and see his wife insulted? If I did that to my own apes, they would kill me. And with my dying breath, I would say... Cont. 234  77 110 Cont. ill 112 113 ARMANDO (Cont. ) (hoarsely) ‘you were right, dear friends, you were right.' (normal voice) God! Aren't we rude enough to each other without having to be rude to animals? (opening caravan door) And anyway, he didn't mean to kill the boy. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I'm very grateful, Armando.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (in doorway) You helped to deliver our last baby. Come and deliver our next. LEWIS takes his vet's bag from beside a Sony TV set on @ table with lace cloth; and ARMANDO walks him into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tney pass a humbler caravan on whose steps a MALE and FEMALE MIDGET sit smoking.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (genially) Hercules! Brunhilde! It's time you were in bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRUNHILDE
dialogues.text: (coy2y) We've been in bed. ARMANDO smiles and waves good night. He and LEWIS reach:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On either side of its entrance are cages -- three with LIONS, three with TIGERS, who placidly grunt and yawn as ARMANDO and LEWIS pass between them into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim and shadowy, for the audience has long gone home. Again, there are three "indoor" cages flanking each side of the entrance; and only the middle cage in the RIGHT- hand sector -- containing the as yet unseen CORNELIUS and ZIRA -- is lit by a single hanging electric bulb which faintly illuminates the entire scene. From the shadows STEVIE runs, relieved, to LEWIS and ARMANDO. Cont.  234 78 113 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lewis, = thought you'd never come! Armando's been a saint.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (smiling) A minor one. St. Francis would have fixed it better.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: Never! Look what we've done. We INTERCUT CHIMPS in cages, during:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (showing first cage) Here we have put the bad-tempered and troublesome Nero. He gets headaches and, like his namesake... ideas. His brain is growing faster than his crenium.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: It's endemic among young chimps--

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: --and incurable.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (sadly) I know. He will have to leave. NERO slaps his aching head and pounds the floor of the cage.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (showing second cage) Here we have bundled the rest of the troupe, including Heloise, Abelard and -- Salome, your god- daughter. His eyes guiltily swivel heavenwards at this minimal blasphemy and he crosses himself. Over a shot of HELOISE suckling (model of) SALOME:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (9.8., proudly) The only chimp ever born in a circus. Back to:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Los Angeles has had four. Cont.  234 79 113 Cont.1

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (with scorn) Los Angeles is not a circus. It is a z00.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: So New Yorkers say. ARMANDO does a double-take and begins to laugh, but puts a finger to his lips before obliquely pointing, with elaborate secrecy, through connecting bars to third (lit) cage.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: (smiling; whispers) Look. Obliquely (through front bars of second cage and side bars contiguous with third) we see a vague FIGURE prowl- ing back and forth. Then ARMANDO tiptoes LEWIS and STEVIE in front of third cage, where we clearly see CORNELIUS ... pacing up and down like any anxious husbard about to become a father. In shadow at the cage's rear lies ZIRA, head towards and feet away from us. In whispers, as CORNELIUS abstractedly paces:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: And here are your friends ... who are now alsc mine.

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: We cleaned it out ourselves. And the mattress is Armando's.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I am used to sleeping hard. He has spoken aloud. CORNELIUS stops his pacing and sees...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Lewis! (striding urgently to bars) I was not responsible for the death --

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (taking his hand) I know. (smiling) But ypu will shortly be responsible for a birth. How is she? Cont.  234 80 113 Cont.2 114

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: The pains come every five minutes. From b.g.:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (the truth, as always) Every four. CORNELIUS resumes his abstracted pacing and is unaware of a minor commotion as HELOISE (in second cage) pushes past other CHIMPANZEES to display SALOME through the bars to ZIRA, who rolls over on her side to inspect the baby.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (through bars to Salome Ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma...(ad lib). This is too much for the nerves of:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Zira, don't waste your breath and your strength! You know that a child born of two primitive apes will never talk.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I'm getting into practice. (to Salome) Ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma-ma -- Her face contorts. She gives a deep cry of pain, as we:

dialogues.speaker: BULB HANGING IN UPPER FRAME
dialogues.text: LEWIS's arm rises into shot from LOWER FRAME, triumphantl holding (model) BABY upside down by its legs and slapping it repeatedly to maintain breathing. Once this is assured we PULL BACK to include LEWIS giving BABY to ZIRA, who lies with her back to us. She displays BABY to the kneel- ing CORNELIUS, who rapturously stares and stares and stares. At length:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: What are we going to call...?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (smiiing) Him. Cont.  234 81 114 Cont. 115 116

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Milo. We PULL BACK further through the front bars to include STEVIE and ARMANDO watching. ARMANDO is lighting a cigar -- presumably for himself. But as CORNELIUS, the proud father, advances to receive congratulations, ARMANDO offers the cigar through the bars to CORNELIUS, who has seen enough of America to know what to do with it. He puffs it -- once professionally, and a second time catastrophically. As he coughs and coughs:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (hoarsely) No. He returns cigar to ARMANDO, who smokes it.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (at wit's end) Where would Apes go? E.1. suddenly halts. After a beat: E.1. To other Apes.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (light dawning) You're right! Search every zoo, every menagerie, every circus...! cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is breakfasting, at the lace-covered table, off fried egg and sausage; but the egg has congealed on a cold plate and the sausage remains impaled, uneaten, on his upraised fork as he bodefully watches his Sony TV set or the same table. We CLOSE TO:  82

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Bones, muscles, tendons, veins, arteries, kidneys, livers, hearts, stomachs, reproductive organs--

dialogues.speaker: E.1.'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Of the dead?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Of the living! ARMANDO slowly lowers his sausage-impaled fork to the cold plate, which he pushes away.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: There was one who ... somehow ... died. He possessed a unique skin. We had it stuffed and put in our museum. It was black. As TV screen momentarily FADES:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (a mutter) Lewis was right. They've faked the tapes. You can almost hear the joins... TV screen FADES IN:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: That recording of the female ape's confession to the C.I.A. will be repeated on KABC regular news bulletins at 4:30, 5:30 and 11:00 p.m. Two big (photographic) HEADS of CORNELIUS and ZIRA flash up in b.g. during:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, the latest news is that the search for the Killer Apes has been switched to zoos, menageries and circuses in the Los Angeles area... ARMANDO rises abrupt _y.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ..-where it's thought they may be seeking their own kind. Cont. 234  234 83 117 Cont. 118

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: Bastards! As he leaves caravan, without switching off set:

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Stay tuned for Movie Mystery, following a commercial. The TV screen now fills ours; and up comes a memory of happier days: the "Chiquita Banana" commercial, from which we:

dialogues.speaker: APES' CAGE
dialogues.text: The electric bulb has been switched off and the light comes only from the morning sun filtering through the thick tent canvas of the Big Top. We PULL BACK from CLOSE SHOT: BABY MILO, asleep on the mattress -- all but the back of his little head wrapped in a rough, dark blanket which (SPECIAL EFFECT!) rises and falls in rhythm with his breathing. ZIRA squats solicitously beside him. ARMANDO paces up and down as frustratedly as did CORNELIUS, who now sits motionless on a wooden stool, staring gloomily ahead with his chin cupped in his hands. STEVIE watches them from outside the bars.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: I had planned it all so well! In a month we move on to our winter quarters in Florida. I could have released you in the Everglades and -- oh, my dear, dear friends! -- you might have lived happily ever after. But now ... those phony tapes, that one accidental death, will turn the people against you. And all zoos, menageries and circuses are to be searched. (in despair) So what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: You have done enough to make us grateful to you forever. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 118 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Why did you do it, Armando?

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: I did it because I like chimpanzees best of all apes, and you the best of all chimpanzees. I da it because I hate those who try to alter Destiny, which is the unalterable will of God. If it is Man's destiny one day to be dominated, then please God let him be dominated by such as you. Dear friends, before the police come and the audience gathers, you and your pretty baby must go. From outside the bars:

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: I'll call Lewis. As she slips away:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: All I can now do to help you is give you this -- for the child. From his pocket he takes a little medal on a short chain, to which we CLOSE, during:

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It is a medal of St. Francis of Assissi. We PULL BACK as he gives the medal to ZIRA, who studies it curiously with CORNELIUS peering over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (smiling) He was ... a holy man who loved and cared for all animals. Hang it around the baby's neck. For protection.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Thank you. (deat) And Armando? Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 118 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: I should like to say good-bye to Heloise.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: If only she could speak, she would say how sorry--

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (quietly) I know. We understand each other. He looks at her, interested; and opens the adjacent cage. Picking up the blanketed BABY MILO, she approaches and enters:

dialogues.speaker: A-118 THE NEXT CAGE
dialogues.text: All the CHIMPS are quiet; but none so quiet as HELOISE, squatting in the shadows with BABY SALOME at her breast. ZIRA squats opposite her, a yard away, with BABY MILO in her lap. For five seconds the two mothers survey each other -- motionless, silent and with grave sympathy -- in a MASTER SHOT from which we CUT AWAY once to MED. SHOT of HELOISE and once (for longer) to MED. SHOT of ZIRA. Then we slowly TRACK IN to CLOSEUP of ZIRA, on whom we:

dialogues.speaker: AND
dialogues.text: Cur IN: 234  234

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DAY
dialogues.text: approaches and halts outside:

dialogues.speaker: ENTRANCE TO LOS ANGELES, (NEW)
dialogues.text: where outcoming OFFICERS are clambering back into three police cars and an attendant ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: (through car window) Any luck?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: No, sir. Another blank. We CLOSE to HASSLEIN channeling his frustration into a single sharp foot-jab on the accelerator.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: There must be a way ... The engine (in neutré1) snarls on his behalf as we: cuT TO: our

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVIE driving. LEWIS beside her with map. APES and blanketed BABY lying down (for concealment) in rear, to which LEWIS now swivels in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Can you read a map?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: I'm an archeologist. I can even draw one. LEWIS lets map unroll over the back of his seat, where CORNELIUS (on his stomach) can read it.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (indicating) We're at the southern edge of this oil field here. And here is as far as we dare take you, because we've got to get back for the night search. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 123 Cont. LEWIS (Cont.) (apologetic smile) We're supposed to be what's called an ‘integral part' of it. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HELICOPTER OVER CIRCUS AREA
dialogues.text: We ZOOM DOWN to Big Top and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE searching ape cages in which APES (except for NERO) have been redistributed. ARMANDO, accompanying POLICE, pretends to be very, very bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey derricks, like clustering Eiffel Towers. Grey pumps like Iron Age birds, rhythmically pecking for the grit that will turn their eggs golden. And, between them, grey scrub tufted with grey grass whose sap has run dry as lunar dust. We are on a moon, landscaped and arch- itected by Man. We END with LONG SHOT ANGLED DOWN from steep hillside: the station wagon -- a grey beetle with side-lit eyes, scuttling to concealment off the highway, and halting. Its beetle-wing doors flap open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS tries to counter the intense emotion of this farewell moment by being brisk and practical -- but never really succeeds. A few scattered lights switch on among the derricks as darkness falls, during:

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Look out for the night watchmen. (holding map in dimmed headlights) But once you're over that hill, you're in more open country. Strike west from here and you'll hit a disused ship's graveyard. ZIRA wraps the BABY warmer against the beginnings of a night breeze, which blows loose tufts of grass about her feet.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I used to play there when I was a kid. Nothing but hulks, mostly. But you could rest and hide there and get your strength back before you move on.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (dismally) On? Below them, a truck roars along the highway. LEWIS looks uneasily over his shoulder and back at map. Cont. 234  87 127 Cont.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: From the ship's graveyard it's @ night's walk to this creek, where there's a cave here. Not a fancy one, so no one goes -- except... (mustering a smile) «myself, when young. But there's fresh water and berries--

dialogues.speaker: STEVIE
dialogues.text: And we'd try to see you and bring you supplies. Again the night breeze. The BABY whimpers.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (rocking it) Ma-ma-ma-ma-ma... Her voice trails to silence.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: It's dark enough to get going. But CORNELIUS is looking at the BABY.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: If they find us, we shall be killed?

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (with unwilling honesty) Ultimately.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Then give us the chance to kill ourselves when ... if the moment comes. A long beat, in which LEWIS's hand goes to his pocket ».-. and stays there.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Please. Cont. 234  234 88 127 Cont.1 128 129

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I shouldn't give you this. (handing a pistol to Cornelius) But I guessed you might ask. (wry smile) It was loaned to me by the C.I.A. for my safety. Now it's for yours ... and Milo'ts. ZIRA, carrying BABY, has joined GROUP in front of dimmed headlights.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: You're the second Human I've kissed. She puts her muzzle to his lips, as we saw her do to Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (diffidently to Stevie) And you're the first. He kisses STEVIE, whose eyes are wet; then grabs ZIRA, almost harshly, by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Come along, Zira! Don't dawdle! He hauls her off unceremoniously into the swallowing darkness, leaving LEWIS and STEVIE (their backs to us) watching them recede. We ZOOM TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to her in angry profile.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (as harshly as Cornelius) Stop hanging about!

dialogues.speaker: OIL FIELD
dialogues.text: NOTE: Our Director's more detailed reconnaissance of the Wilmington and San Pedro LOCATIONS should yield abundant material for a MONTAGE laden with nocturnal menace. Finally, after a steep, exhausting ascent during which CORNELIUS takes the BABY and almost crushes it by stumbling forwards on slippery ground, they achieve:  234 130 131 89

dialogues.speaker: HILLTOP
dialogues.text: Below, the tall derricks abut on the more distantly glimmering tanks of the refinery. Nothing in Ape City ever looked so eerie as this; and ZIRA points an alarmed finger at the tanks.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Who lives in those? But CORNELIUS is looking elsewhere at darker, more open country beyond.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: We're over the hill. (taking bearings from the stars) Now we go west. (over-optimistically) This'll be easier. Take Milo and keep behind me. I want to be sure all's clear. They begin:

dialogues.speaker: THE DESCENT
dialogues.text: More perilous than the climb, for the hill's farther slop is steeper and more slippery. Using DOUBLES when necessar we increasingly speed up CUTTING TEMPO as: A. CORNELIUS starts sure-footedly towards: B. Derrick at hill's base. c. ZIRA (with BABY) starts sure-footedly, but: D. The slope steepens. E. She begins involuntarily to run... F. .+.faster and fester... G. ++.-until out of control. H. CORNELIUS, appailed; not daring to shout. He traverses the slope to intercept her, but: I. She collides with him; falls on her back, holding the squealing BABY protectively high, and: J. Slides past CORNELIUS, towards: K. Derrick, looming. Cont.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 131 Cont. 132 133 13h 23h L. CORNELIUS, helplessly reacting. M Derrick, looming nearer. N. CORNELIUS hides his eyes. Oo ZIRA barely grazes derrick, one of whose sharp girders... P. ...retains a shred of her torn dress. MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he stumbles frantically down slope (dislodging a few small rocks which avalanche behind him) into shot with:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: sitting bolt upright in the grass and quietening the BABY

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (authoritatively) Ma-ma-ma-ma-ma...

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (helping her up and taking Baby) Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (rubbing her back) Except I feel like I've been branded.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Then let's get going. (looking about) We made a bit of noise. As they recede westwards into the darkness, we PULL BACK to include base of derrick with the shred of ZIRA's dress still attached to a lower girder. Then we SLOW-ZOOM FORWARD to:

dialogues.speaker: DARK PRINT
dialogues.text: We hold this for three seconds until (over FADED-UP SOUND of bloodnounds barking and yapping) the DARK PRINT slowly and artificially brightens to the intensity of:  234

dialogues.speaker: DAY PRINT, (SAME AS SCENE 134)
dialogues.text: The barking PEAKS. A POLICE BLOODHOUND's nose pushes into FRAME and excitedly nuzzles and sniffs the shred. Then another nose. And another. We ZOOM BACK to: FULL PANORAMIC SHOT (DAY) - LAST NIGHT'S TERRAIN... .«..now fizzing and swarming with ant-like POLICE activit under the hot midday sun. We INTERCUT: - HANDLERS struggling to restrain their hysterically yapping bloodhounds. - FINGERPRINT EXPERTS insufflating the telltale girder. - A POLICE SQUAD, in extended order, combing the downward hill slope and noting signs of disturbance. Meanwhile: ON THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL STANDS HASSLEIN... ... lowering angled-down binoculars to reveal cold, triumphant eyes. As a distant whistle blows, he sees: P.O.V. LONG SHOT - BLOODHOUNDS STARTING TO FOLLOW SCENT.. +..with POLICE in jeeps behind.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING UP, (MED. CLOSE)
dialogues.text: He consults a map, whose indications his eyes compare with the direction of the chase. Then he briskly folds up map and disappears behind summit in what we know to be the direction of the highway.

dialogues.speaker: WEARY APES, (WITH BABY)
dialogues.text: and look up at:

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL SCRAPYARD
dialogues.text: We TILT DOWN from sign to the tall wire fence beneath. It has long since ceased to fulfill its protective function. A second sign ("NO TRESPASSING") -- so pocked with rust that it is almost illegible -- dangles diagonally from eroded wire mesh in which spiders may safely spin. TILT ENDS on torn gap at fence's base. CORNELIUS's hand reaches into LOWER RIGHT of FRAME and tugs at wire above gap. It snaps like trellis with dry rot; and we PULL BACK to see CORNELIUS tugging away enough wire to widen the gap -- through which he and ZIRA (with BABY) now enter:  234 142 143 144 145 92

dialogues.speaker: OUTER SCRAPYARD
dialogues.text: We PAN APES along a rutted road past mountainous dumps of nautical trash: mildewed timber, huge propellers leprous with dead mollusks, metal tubes that look as if they would snap like cheese sticks, and, all alone, a smashed glass dial that used to register "FULL SPEED AHEAD" but now registers ... "STOP". At the road's end, which is the water's edge, CORNELIUS and ZIRA halt and look uneasily ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: The ship's graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Only for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shanty town of ships that have died'without burial -- beached on the mud or berthed in scummy water to rot and rust under the sun and the salt air. Laid out haphazardly, like corpses after a plague, they still carry traces of their former finery about them, as a skeleton may wear jewels: jet-black mussels choking the iron neck of an anchor; a bollard's head, tiara'd with barnacles; limpet-rings round the two splayed fingers of a cleat; and a gangway (which the APES now gingerly cross) jumping and swinging like the necklace on a Balinese dancer. Perhaps the ships are not quite dead. For sometimes, on the slack tide, they move with an arthritic creak or touch one another with a groan -- these poor, amputated hulks who once rode the ocean as proudly and delicately as dolphins. The APES step aboard and survey:

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: A decrepit coastal craft, sawn off clean at the stern which is wedged against the sea wall, her aft super- structure (whose paint has flaked like an old whore's) rises in three tiers of arched entrances to cabins. We CLOSE to one of these and:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE
dialogues.text: It has reached the refinery tanks, through which the yapping bloodhounds now weave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is driving at speed - we know not whither.

dialogues.speaker: APES
dialogues.text: ZIRA sits in the cabin entrance, her blanketed BABY on her lap, her legs dangling over the top-tier catwalk -- for all the world like a grandmother taking the sun on her stoop. We INTERCUT shots of putrescence and pollution during:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Did Lewis really play here?

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Perhaps it was cleaner then.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: It stinks of Man.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (charitably) That's oil. And dead fish.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Is that what Man wanted oil for? To kill fish? The BABY begins to cry. She absently rocks it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: You don't like them, do you?

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: We've met hundreds here -- and I trust three, (to Baby) Ma-ma-ma-ma... But the BABY goes on crying.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: He wants feeding. Cont. 234  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 148 Cont. As she prepares to suckle BABY:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (a patent hint to Cornelius) So do I. CORNELIUS rises and stretches in the hot sun.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: I'll look for berries. Stay here till I come back. (looking about) All's quiet. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE CHASE
dialogues.text: It isn't quiet here. Jeeps roar, bloodhounds yap, and dust rises from open country beyond the refinery tanks, which are still visible in distant b.g. cut TO:  234 150 151 152 153 154 94

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: denuding a dusty bush of its few dusty berries, which he puts carefully in a rusty can. He cautiously straightens; looks landward and seaward; then moves off -- maybe in search of more berries, maybe to go "home".

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING BEHIND AND THROUGH WIRE FENCE
dialogues.text: including the back of the diagonally dangling "NO TRESPASSING" sign. Through mesh we see HASSLEIN's Mercedes (dusty now) slowly approaching us from MED. to CLOSE SHOT. It stops just short of fence. HASSLEIN alights; peers speculatively about him; looks up at big sign; then lower at small sign; then down at the fence's foot ... where the freshly torn wire intrigues him, for he touches and feels it. He enters through gap and, passing CAMERA, moves cautiously out of shot.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA IN CABIN ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: The BABY asleep on her lap. The sun is very hot. ZIRA herself begins to nod into a doze; then (with a start) realizes that she must not sleep exposed, but only in concealment. She rises with BABY and enters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty dark, for the sunlight barely filters through the two filthy scupper panes. And you wouldn't know it was a cabin, because all the furniture has long since been removed. She adjusts the blanket so that it will serve both as a wrap and a pillow for the BABY; then herself lies down on the bare boards (from which a cockroach scuttles) with her head near the BABY. We SLOW-TRACK IN to CLOSEUP of her tired eyes. The heavy lids blink ++. droop ... and fall. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN APPROACHING THE WATER'S EDGE
dialogues.text: He looks speculatively at the ship. A possibility? He approaches the gangway. Tests it with his foot. The timber is serviceable and it holds. He starts walking up the gangway -- and at his fourth step realizes that, though it holds, it sways ... and rattles.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA'S EYES
dialogues.text: They are open but not alarmed. She has woken but is not aware that anything waked her. We STAY on her eyes for three long seconds. Then the gangway rattles again -- louder. Alert, she rises on one elbow.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (calling) Cornelius?

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN...
dialogues.text: ...Kbaving achieved the deck, stops dead in his tracks. He was moving, with his back to us, in the wrong direction. Now he turns into CAMERA; and from his face we Know that he has heard not only the call but the name that was called. He heads noiselessly in the vague direction of the sound's source, passing CAMERA, which PANS to his stealthily receding back and FOLLOWS him as he climbs towards the seaward end of the catwalk. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING ALONG CATWALK FROM SEAWARD END
dialogues.text: HASSLEIN, still with his back to us, walks from seaward towards landward end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZIRA hears the footsteps with relief. It must be her husband, home again. She rises, picks up BABY and makes for the cabin door.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING LANDWARD ALONG CATWALK
dialogues.text: HASSLEIN is approaching the landward end in b.g., when ZIRA in f.g. (with BABY) peers out of cabin entrance and looks seaward, where the footsteps were coming from.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Cornelius? Hearing the quick scrape of a shoe suddenly turning, she spins round to confront:

dialogues.speaker: P.0.V. FLASH
dialogues.text: Five yards off and facing her with a revolver not yet aimed.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: Quick glance into cabin door. No, she'd be trapped there. Swiftly she backs to catwalk's seaward end; stoops and sets the crying BABY down on the Catwalk, a little to one side and behind her so she can step in front to protect it. As she straightens:

dialogues.speaker: THE BLANKET TWITCHES TWICE...
dialogues.text: .»..and, as the crying cuts out, is still.

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN WITH REVOLVER AIMED
dialogues.text: advances step by step on ZIRA. At his second step, we may or may not notice the o.s. gangplank rattle once. At his fourth step, a gun fires. The bullet hits him in the RIGHT side of the neck. For a second, he stands quite still. Then, almost apologetically to ZIRA:

dialogues.speaker: HASSLEIN
dialogues.text: Somebody had to begin to ... care. The last word is less a word than a cough; and the cough is bloody. HASSLEIN's eyes glaze, as he pitches forward. Over the thud of his fall:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS ON GANGWAY
dialogues.text: Lowering Lewis's pistol. On SOUND, we reprise CRESCENDO MUSIC mimicking the high-string "scream" in his head (which he heard when he knew he had killed the Orderly) and we HOLD "scream" until he speaks. Now he staggers dumbly up the swaying, clattering gangway crosses the cluttered deck to the seaward rail, and clamb up the catwalk companionway to:

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA BY SHIP'S SEAWARD RAIL
dialogues.text: As CORNELIUS precipitately enters shot, the "scream™ thins and FADES for:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (sobbing) Zira, I've killed two men. I'm @ murderer, Zira. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 166 Cont. 167 168 169 170 171 Hysterically he hurls LEWIS's offending pistol into the sea. We hear the splash as she takes him in her arms. And, in the first silence, we (but not yet they) become aware of the faint barking of bloodhounds. Now, with shamed, down-hanging head profiled against ZIRA's breast, CORNELIUS sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE STILL BLANKET
dialogues.text: Between the ship's rail and ZIRA's feet. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Is the baby...? He cannot say the word "dead". And now our blood crawls. For ZIRA's RIGHT foot jabs savagely backwards, kicking the blanket and its small corpse under the ship's rail and into the sea. Over a splash louder than the pistol's:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Still profiled against his wife's breast and looking up questioningly at:

dialogues.speaker: P.0O.V. BIG HEAD
dialogues.text: She is sneering. And we hold this inexplicable reaction until the barking bloodhounds and the wailing sirens grow loud enough to wipe it off her face, as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZIRA imperiously beckoning CORNELIUS to the seaward companionway's head.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE SEARCH ERUPTS INTO GRAVEYARD AREA
dialogues.text: Bloodhounds, handlers, jeeps, an ambulance and blue-winki shrill-sirened cars which eject more Police Officers. The noise deafens. We PICK OUT one bloodhound hauling its handler up the landward companionway to nose out ... HASSLEIN's corpse.

dialogues.speaker: HANDLER
dialogues.text: (yelling down) They're armed! cut TO:

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 172 173 174 175 234 ZIRA RACING AHEAD OF CORNELIUS... ...towards the gangway.

dialogues.speaker: ZIRA
dialogues.text: (without looking round; yells) Cornelius! Get off the ship!

dialogues.speaker: THEIR BLOODHOUNDS
dialogues.text: which converge, in a snarling torrent, on the gangway. ZIRA is only halfway down it, when the "torrent" hits her and she goes under. When the bloodhounds disperse, she lies on the gangplank, lacerated, bleeding and in mortal pain. A CAPTAIN and a POLICE OFFICER clatter up the gangway. The CAPTAIN looks down.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (curtly) Put her out of her misery. We STAY on POLICE OFFICER only, as he shoots her.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: farther back and higher up, amidships. Yelling down at the top of his lungs:

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Scum! Filthy, smooth-skinned, human scum! CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: DOCKSIDE
dialogues.text: and looks up. E.l. Come quietly, Cornelius.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Quietly? We all came quietly, wanting to be your friends and wishing you no harm. uietly? When you've killed everything I had left to love? Now kill me. Or... (right hand creeping to pocket) ++eI'l] kill you. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: REVISED
dialogues.text: 175 Cont. 176 177 178 We know the pistol is in the sea. We know CORNELIUS is suicidally drawing their fire. But the POLICE know nothing, and E.1. fires -- accurately at CORNELIUS's right hand. CORNELIUS looks at the hand in scorn.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: I said kill me. Bloody hand in pocket, he begins to walk down towards the gangway, simulating a gun-muzzle with two (pocketed) fingers. E.1.'s gun fires twice -- hitting CORNELIUS in the chest and shoulder. CORNELIUS walks on. The CAPTAIN turns to the POLICE OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: (it could be with compassion) Let him have it. POLICE OFFICER aims and fires his rifle. The bullet hits CORNELIUS above the heart. At the gangway's head, he halts, sways, takes his maimed right hand (unarmed) out of his pocket and holds it over the death wound.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (looking down gangway) You can't break my heart any more. You broke it when... He pitches forward. The gangway clatters as he slides down it, face foremost, until his dead cheek touches ZIRA's.

dialogues.speaker: STATION WAGON VIOLENTLY HALTING IN REAR OF POLICE
dialogues.text: LEWIS and STEVIE push through, to confront:

dialogues.speaker: DOCKSIDE AND SHIP
dialogues.text: As an ambulance draws up at the foot of the gangway where POLICE are laying out the two BODIES, another OFFICER enters LEFT FRAME, carrying a third. A very small body, and naked. The OFFICER sets it down between ZIRA and CORNELIUS. Cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING DOWN OVER BACKS OF STEVIE AND LEWIS
dialogues.text: as they survey the holocaust. Suddenly and in need of comfort, he puts a hand almost fiercely on her shoulder and turns into bitter profile. Cont.  234

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Hasslein was right: It had to be done. We CRANE steeply BACK and UP to include a full aerial shot of the scene, as the bodies are lifted into the ambulance and the ambulance drives away. Now, while the CAMERA still soars, we OVERLAP on SOUND: the noise of sleepy lions grunting, the squeak and gibber of smaller animals, the whinnying of horses, and the soft thud of a mallet on wood.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO'S CIRCUS
dialogues.text: The Big Top is being lowered and spectacularly balloons to earth behind crates (being lifted onto trucks), caravans, generators ... and a line of wheeled animal cages which ARMANDO is approaching from b.g., as we TRACK past cages and more slowly approach him. The lions grunt. The tigers snarl. Dogs and CIRCUS HANDS distantly bark and shout. We TRACK ON IN to profiled CLOSE SHOT of ARMANDO. He has paused at the head of the line by a cage whose contents he masks.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDO
dialogues.text: (throwaway ) Intelligent creature! But then, SO... (crossing himself) ...were your mother and father. (shouting o.s.) Ready to move in five minutes ... ! He walks out of shot between cage and CAMERA, unmasking (as we CLOSE) an infant CHIMPANZEE. It stands, clutching the bars of the cage through which it stares intently and alertly. Then, in an opportune silence:

dialogues.speaker: BABY CHIMP
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) Ma-ma-ma-ma-ma... It continues with increasing enthusiasm to declaim the first words (if you can call them that) ever uttered by an ape born in captivity. We MOVE IN close enough to identify the medal of St. Francis round its small neck.
